page.title: 11Caerphilly Cheese
page.content: The making of farm cheese dates from early primitive times. On Medieval farms it was one of the duties of the farmer's wife and daughters and has remained so up until 1939. The Caerphilly cheese market was an open building into which the farmers could drive their wagons to unload their wares. It was always well attended and the weekly sale often amounted to two and a half tons. The Roath Manor records contained entries concerning the sale of one hundred and thirty stone of cheese in 1316. From Caerphilly, cheese was sent by road and rail to S. Wales mining valleys, the coastal towns and Bristol. Owing to increased industrialisation locally, causing heavier demand for milk, the market closed in 1910.
